docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re the Jan. 3 letter about the book burning in Alamogordo, N.M.:    As a former New York resident and a 22-year resident of Alamogordo, I can say that the great majority of its residents don't share the feelings of the minister a...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Jan. 3 letter about the book burning in Alamogordo, N.M.: As a former New York resident and a 22-year resident of Alamogordo, I can say that the great majority of its residents don't share the feelings of the minister and the congregation of the church that burned the Shakespeare and Harry Potter books.
docs.abstract: Letter from Bob La Rosa, resident of Alamagordo, NM, says Jan 3 letter about book burning in Alamagordo is not condoned by great majority of city's residents

docs.snippet: After three weeks of tensions on the border with India, Pakistan has taken several steps to reduce the threat of war with its neighbor. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, was reported this week to have cut his government's military and i...
docs.lead_paragraph: After three weeks of tensions on the border with India, Pakistan has taken several steps to reduce the threat of war with its neighbor. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, was reported this week to have cut his government's military and intelligence links with two Islamic extremist groups operating in India, and to have arrested an estimated 100 militant leaders. These actions were in some ways even tougher for Pakistan than its earlier decision to cooperate with the United States' war on terrorism and sever ties with the Taliban in Afghanistan. India has had a mixed response. But it should reciprocate by reducing some forces on its side of the border. For many years, Pakistan has denied that it had anything official to do with the groups on its soil that have been aiding an Islamic uprising in the disputed northern Indian border state of Kashmir. General Musharraf and his predecessors have all spoken of Pakistan offering ''moral support'' but little else. Now, in a sudden turnaround, Pakistani officials are acknowledging not only that these groups have operated with government aid and encouragement, but that they have been responsible for most of the attacks in recent years on civilians in Kashmir, which is India's only Muslim-dominated state. India charges that Pakistan-based groups were also behind an assault on India's Parliament on Dec. 13 in which 14 died, including the 5 attackers.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails steps by Pakistan to reduce threat of war with India by cutting links with two Islamic extremist groups operating in India; urges India to respond by reducing military buildup at border

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Death Sentence Overturned in 1981 Killing of Officer'' (news article, Dec. 19): I hope that one result of the overturning of the death penalty against Mumia Abu-Jamal will be a refined media and political focus on the inequa...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Death Sentence Overturned in 1981 Killing of Officer'' (news article, Dec. 19): I hope that one result of the overturning of the death penalty against Mumia Abu-Jamal will be a refined media and political focus on the inequality of death penalty sentencing around the country. In Pennsylvania, 70 percent of the 244 death row inmates are either African-American or Hispanic, and 90 percent of those on death row had to rely on court-appointed or pro bono lawyers for their trials.
docs.abstract: Neal Kronley letter, commenting on Dec 19 article, deplores preponderance of blacks and Hispanics on death rows of American prisons

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Radicalism: Is the Devil in the Demographics?'' (Week in Review, Dec. 9):    America's war on terrorism is being waged in the military and propaganda spheres. We have to extend it into the educational and economic arena. Wha...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Radicalism: Is the Devil in the Demographics?'' (Week in Review, Dec. 9): America's war on terrorism is being waged in the military and propaganda spheres. We have to extend it into the educational and economic arena. What is needed are conditional grants to the overpopulated Arab and Islamic countries to help them develop agricultural and light-industrial projects away from urban centers to create employment, especially for youths.
docs.abstract: Letter from Haskel M Haddad, president, World Orgn for Jews From Arab Countries, says America's war on terrorism should include conditional grants to overpopulated Arab and Islamic countries to help them develop agricultural and light-industry projects away from urban centers to create employment, especially for youths

docs.snippet: From childhood, Mohamed Moulessehoul dreamed of being a writer. Yet by the time his fiction was recognized, no one knew he was the author.    As an Algerian army officer, he was required to present his manuscripts for approval by military censors....
docs.lead_paragraph: From childhood, Mohamed Moulessehoul dreamed of being a writer. Yet by the time his fiction was recognized, no one knew he was the author. As an Algerian army officer, he was required to present his manuscripts for approval by military censors. To circumvent this rule, he adopted a woman's pseudonym. So it was as Yasmina Khadra that he became known in Algeria and Western Europe.
docs.abstract: Article on Mohamed Moulessehoul, Algerian army officer, now retired, who wrote several novels under female pseudonym, Yasmina Khadra; Moulessehoul has moved to South of France but, once having to camouflage fact that he was writer, now finds himself criticized for fighting in bloody civil war; photos (M)

docs.snippet: The night before the world got the news of Daniel Pearl's death, you could hear another reporter describing the perils of his profession in a talk carried on  C-Span. The journalist was Bernard Goldberg, formerly of CBS News and author of the best...
docs.lead_paragraph: The night before the world got the news of Daniel Pearl's death, you could hear another reporter describing the perils of his profession in a talk carried on C-Span. The journalist was Bernard Goldberg, formerly of CBS News and author of the best-selling ''Bias,'' and his story was tragic. Mr. Goldberg, you see, had once written an op-ed piece in The Wall Street Journal criticizing his network for what he saw as its liberal bias, and the price he paid for this act of courage was steep. His fellow employees considered him radioactive. They treated him like a pariah. And then came the ultimate indignity: Dan Rather stopped talking to him!
docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column examines what he sees as Bush administration's attempts to stymie reporters who specialize in kind of investigative inquiry such as Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl was pursuing when he was ambushed; other examples cited (M)

docs.snippet: TOWNSEND-M. Wilbur. Retired chairman and CEO of Handy and Harman in New York City, died on February 7, 2002 in Ormond Beach, Florida at the age of 90 due to heart complications. Born in Oyster Bay, New York on January 17, 1912, Bill graduated from...
docs.lead_paragraph: TOWNSEND-M. Wilbur. Retired chairman and CEO of Handy and Harman in New York City, died on February 7, 2002 in Ormond Beach, Florida at the age of 90 due to heart complications. Born in Oyster Bay, New York on January 17, 1912, Bill graduated from Choate in 1930 and from Wesleyan University in 1934 where he earned a Phi Beta Kappa key. During World War II, Mr. Townsend worked in Washington, D.C. at the War Manpower Commission. In 1946 he joined Handy and Harman and in 1964 became chairman, president and CEO. Under his leadership the company was listed on the New York Stock Exchange on May 1, 1967. Mr. Townsend was active as a member of the boards of Home Life Insurance Company, Lazare Kaplan, the Jewelers Security Alliance, the Jewelers Vigilance committee, the Jewelers Industry Council and the 24 Karat Club of NYC, president in 1972 and then chairman for 3 years. Married for 62 years to Barbara Hayden, they lived most of their lives in Scarsdale, N.Y. They were members of the Greenville Community Church where Bill was a Deacon and an Elder. He was a member of the Union League Club and the Westchester Country Club. In addition to his wife, Barbara, Bill was predeceased by his sister, Sally. He is survived by his two sons, Barrett Townsend of Greenwich, CT., and Philip Townsend of Eastchester, N.Y. Also surviving are 3 grandchildren & 4 great grandchildren.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, M. WILBUR

docs.snippet: Heinrich Dietrich Schutz, an art dealer and fine art publisher, died on Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.    The cause was vascular disease, said his wife, Suzanne....
docs.lead_paragraph: Heinrich Dietrich Schutz, an art dealer and fine art publisher, died on Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 and lived in Greenwich, Conn. The cause was vascular disease, said his wife, Suzanne.
docs.abstract: Heirich Dietrich Schutz, art dealer and fine art publisher, diees at age 79 (M)

headline.main: Heinrich Schutz, 79, Art Dealer and Editor

docs.snippet: Muhammad Ali, New York City, March 21, 1967    ''That day, I was walking with my brother and my assistant trainer, surrounded by my entourage. I don't remember walking to the weigh-in. You're always nervous before a fight. What's involved is milli...
docs.lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, New York City, March 21, 1967 ''That day, I was walking with my brother and my assistant trainer, surrounded by my entourage. I don't remember walking to the weigh-in. You're always nervous before a fight. What's involved is millions of dollars -- if you lose, your value is going to go down. But I remember the fight the next day. Zora Folley was a very scientific boxer. He wasn't wild. I had to be real careful. You can't make a mistake with him. You'd get it. I couldn't afford to be off-guard. I was dancing around, waiting for him to throw a left jab. ''That was the first time and the last time I fought Zora Folley. It would be my last fight for three and a half years. I had a feeling that it was going to be, but I wasn't sure then. My mind was made up. I had decided not to join the Army. But the Vietnam problem didn't make me fight any harder or less. I fought as hard as I had to to win.
docs.abstract: Muhammad Ali comments on what he was thinking in Mar 21 1967 photo of him taken day before fight3
